data is a simple method for exploring local structure that is highly
sensitive to the displacements of metal atoms associated with the
formation of orbital molecules, metal–metal-bonded clusters such
as the trimerons observed in magnetite
molecules far above their long-range electronic ordering transi-
tions has been discovered from X-ray PDF studies of Li
The thermal variation of local structure in magnetite has been
explored here over a wide temperature range encompassing both
the Verwey and Curie transitions through synchrotron X-ray
Variable temperature PDF analysis of magnetite
details are in the “Methods” section. Total X-ray scattering data
from a highly stoichiometric sample of magnetite were recorded
from 90 to 923 K. Representative scattering intensity
with 168 small (<0.24 Å) displacements of atoms from their
positions in the high temperature cubic spinel structure
the PDFs over all temperatures, we have used this monoclinic
supercell with lattice parameters adjusted to a cubic metric
and with each of the 168 atomic coordinates given by
is the coordinate from an undistorted high-
temperature cubic crystal structure reﬁnement and
coordinate in the distorted 90 K structure reported previously
is a Verwey shift parameter that describes the set of constrained
cubic spinel structure without any local distortions and
describes the full magnitude of distortions in the 90 K magnetite
mined at each temperature by ﬁtting the structural model to three
successive regions of the PDF corresponding approximately to
distances from atoms to their neighbours in the same unit cell
(First Unit Cell range, covering all interatomic distances for
9.36 Å) and similarly to atoms in the Second and Third Unit Cell
regions. The structural models and ﬁtting procedure are further
described in “Methods”, and ﬁts to data and their sensitivity to
Thermal variations of reﬁned structural quantities from the
PDF ﬁts are shown in Fig.
anomaly at the Verwey transition (previously found to be
123.4 K for this highly pure magnetite sample)
monotonically from 150 up to 923 K. The Verwey shift
measures an averaged local structural distortion due to electronic
Unit Cell separations (between atoms 16.8 to 24.6 Å apart) in
b is a typical order-parameter behaviour at a ﬁrst-order
phase transition, with a sharp fall to
. Second Unit Cell correlations have a qualitatively similar
variation although critical ﬂuctuations decay more gradually
and are estimated to persist up to 250–300 K. However,
structural correlations between atoms in the First Unit Cell range
(<9.4 Å apart) show a strikingly different behaviour.
on warming though the Verwey transition, but around 80% of the
structural ﬂuctuations remain in the cubic phase of magnetite up
close to the Curie transition at
≈ 850 K and so behaves like an
order parameter for the magnetic ordering transition with a very
similar temperature dependence to the bulk magnetisation
reported for a similar synthetic microcrystalline magnetite
This is the key discovery of the present study as it demonstrates
that the structural ﬂuctuations responsible for the Verwey
transition emerge directly with the long-range magnetic order
below the Curie transition and scale with the magnetisation.
The thermal variations of the unit cell parameter and isotropic
atomic temperature factors of magnetite plotted in Fig.
our PDF ﬁtting method is robust in decorrelating the overall
lattice expansion and phonon motion, quantiﬁed by the latter
